III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12206
Section Staff qualifications; volunteer, contractors on central registry
Description
1

• (2) A staff member must be of responsible character and
suitable and able to meet the needs of children and families
served by the agency.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Foster care worker has been rude when communicating with a
relative who had placement of a youth.
Investigation Maternal Grandmother was interviewed via telephone on
June 5, 2025. She stated Youth A has been placed in her care for
several years. Maternal Grandmother stated she didn’t have any
issues until about a year ago when Adoption worker was assigned
to Youth A’s case. During the initial visit Adoption worker was very
rude. She was taking videos of her home. She clarified she was
asked prior to recording the visit and Adoption worker explained it
was so she could recall the layout and details of the home for her
report. Maternal Grandmother stated she asked the agency that
Adoption worker not come back to her home and requested a new
worker due to being treated poorly.
Maternal Grandmother was asked for specific examples of how
Adoption worker has been rude to her. She reported the tone of
voice that is used and accusations that are made. Maternal
Grandmother stated she has been accused of utilizing corporal
punishment on 3 separate occasions. She stated that Adoption
worker has never explained the reason for being asked about
corporal punishment. A follow up interview was conducted with
Maternal Grandmother on June 18, 2025, via telephone. She
stated prior to Youth A having unsupervised visitation with
Competing Party in Ohio there were supervised visits held locally
in the community. After one visit at McDonald’s Youth A came
home and informed Maternal Grandmother, he saw Competing
Party give Adoption worker money. She stated that was the only
occasion Youth A told her it happened, and she reported it via
email to DHHS and Youth A’s Lawyer Guardian Ad Litem (LGAL)
at the time.
Substitute Caregiver was interviewed via telephone on June
9, 2025. She stated she has been present during all but one of
Adoption worker’s visits to Maternal Grandmother’s home. She
stated Adoption worker is rude when Maternal Grandmother asks
questions. She provided an example when Maternal Grandmother
asked about visits with Youth A’s paternal grandmother, who is a
competing party on the adoption, after sexual abuse allegations
were brought up. She stated Adoption worker told her they weren’t
going to discuss that at that time. Substitute Caregiver stated she
2

spoke up and informed Adoption worker she was being rude to
Maternal Grandmother. She stated she points out to Adoption
worker every other visit that she is being rude. Anytime they ask
why things are or are not happening and why there are things they
need to complete again, Adoption worker is rude. Substitute
Caregiver stated Adoption worker has also accused Maternal
Grandmother of corporal punishment and does not provide an
explanation for why she is asking or bringing it up.
Substitute Caregiver stated approximately 2-3 months ago she
overheard Youth A tell Maternal Grandmother that an uncle at the
home of the competing party gave Adoption worker money. She
doesn’t think Maternal Grandmother reported that to Adoption
worker but did report it to the LGAL.
Adoption worker was interviewed via telephone on June 10,
2025. She stated she has been assigned to the case since June
2024. She stated Youth A currently resides with Maternal
Grandmother. She isn’t sure why the allegations were reported as
she feels the interactions with Maternal Grandmother have gone
well. She stated there have been some concerns reported
throughout the case, and she is required to address those. She
provided an example of corporal punishment. During a home visit,
Youth A mentioned Maternal Grandmother spanks him, and he
took a belt and hit Maternal Grandmother. Maternal Grandmother
denied, but Adoption worker reminded her of prudent parenting
and discipline policy where no corporal punishment is allowed and
reminded her to use redirection. She stated there was another
agency worker with her during that visit, but she is no longer with
the agency. She stated she was not accusatory or rude but
needed to address it since Youth A reported it.
Other concerns that have been brought up were regarding
Maternal Grandmother’s allowing Youth A’s parents in the home
after termination had occurred. She allowed another adult
daughter who is a known substance abuse user around Youth A.
She stated there was discussion around the concerns and if she
was able to recognize when someone was under the influence.
Maternal Grandmother reported she took her adult daughter to a
known drug house to buy drugs. She stated she needed to
address these concerns and did so in a respectful manner, but
Maternal Grandmother became defensive and took it as she was
being accused. Adoption worker stated Maternal Grandmother
has not been happy with her since she began assessing the
competing party for the adoption process.
3

Adoption worker stated Maternal Grandmother has started video
recording her home visits. She stated she has informed Maternal
Grandmother that if concerns are reported to her, she is required
to address those concerns. She stated she has tried to have
another agency worker accompany her during home visits due to
tension and wants to ensure she has a witness to avoid any false
allegations. Foster Care Worker (FCW) accompanied her on the
majority of the visits. The other workers who accompanied her are
no longer with the agency.
She stated Maternal Grandmother has started having Substitute
Caregiver at the home during any of the foster care or adoption
visits. She believes Maternal Grandmother is also recording the
private meeting with Youth A as well. She states the reason she
believes is because at the last home visit she met with Youth A
and discussed the concerns at the home of competing party.
When they walked out of Youth A’s bedroom, Substitute Caregiver
stated “I got it all on” and Maternal Grandmother told her to send it
to her. She stated she has visited Youth A outside, but he has a
hard time with distractions and ends up riding his bike. She stated
Youth A has been told not to talk to Adoption worker. She
completed a Zoom visit during Youth A’s most recent visit with
Competing Party and at the end of the visit Competing Party
mistakenly left her phone on and she asked Youth A why he
wasn’t talking to Adoption worker, and he said Maternal
Grandmother doesn’t like Adoption worker and told Youth A not to
talk to her. Youth A is more open when Adoption worker has
another worker accompany her but only provides yes or no
responses when it’s just her.
Adoption worker was asked about an allegation of accepting
money from someone connected to the case. She stated she has
never received anything from any of her clients. She stated this is
the first time she has heard of this allegation. She was adamant
she has never received anything from anyone.
Foster Care worker (FCW) was interviewed via telephone on
July 2, 2025. She stated she was previously the assigned foster
care worker for Youth A and accompanied Adoption worker on 2
home visits. FCW stated she never witnessed Adoption worker
being rude or disrespectful to Maternal Grandmother in any way.
There were a few concerns that had been brought to the attention
of the agency and Adoption worker addressed those concerns, but
it was done in a professional manner.
4

Adoption supervisor was interviewed via telephone on June
13, 2025. She stated she has not accompanied Adoption worker
during any of the home visits with Maternal Grandmother. She has
been present during Family Team Meetings (FTM’s), court
hearings and telephone calls where Adoption worker and Maternal
Grandmother interacted, and she did not notice anything that was
concerning or disrespectful toward Maternal Grandmother.
Adoption supervisor stated there have been a number of concerns
brought to their attention regarding Maternal Grandmother. They
are obligated to address the concerns and Adoption supervisor
feels that is where some of the complaint is coming from because
Maternal Grandmother becomes defensive and feels she is being
accused. Adoption supervisor stated they don’t point the finger at
Maternal Grandmother, but Adoption worker explains she is
required to address any concerns that are brought to her attention.
Competing Party was interviewed via telephone on July 7,
2025. She stated there has never been a situation where money
or any type of gift was exchanged between her and Adoption
worker. Her initial visits with Youth A were at McDonald’s and a
few other public locations before progressing to extended
overnight visits at her home in Ohio. Competing Party stated
during those visits Adoption worker sat by herself while she visited
with Youth A. She stated Complainant had previously told her she
will do anything she can to get Adoption worker in trouble and
terminated.
Documents reviewed:
• November 13, 2024, Updated Service Plan (USP). Report
details concern regarding Maternal Grandmother making
comments on Facebook about visiting a known drug house
to drop off an adult daughter and pick up another adult
daughter. Adoption worker addressed this and inquired if
Youth A was with her and reminded her Youth A was not to
have contact with biological parents per court order.
• December 4, 2024, social work contact. Safety plan
established and reviewed with Maternal Grandmother due
to children’s services complaint received in November 2024
due to allegations of physical abuse. Safety plan addresses
methods of discipline. Safety plan was reviewed during
January 2025, February 2025 and March 2025 home visits.
• January 22, 2025, email to DCWL complaints indicating
Adoption worker accepted money from a potential adoptive
family.
5

Analysis The agency is found in compliance. Based on completed
interviews and review of Youth A’s MISACWIS file there were
concerns/allegations brought to the agency’s attention that
needed to be addressed. There is no evidence to suggest
Adoption worker was inappropriate when addressing the concerns
and safety planning with Maternal Grandmother.
In regard to the allegation Adoption worker accepted money from
Competing Party, there is no evidence to suggest that occurred.
During completed interviews with Adoption worker and Competing
Party they both adamantly denied that occurred. Documentation
reviewed shows a dismissed DCWL complaint and emails
provided do not mention any concerns reported from Maternal
Grandmother that mention Adoption worker accepted money from
competing party.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12207 Staff responsibilities
Section • (3) An agency shall require that social service workers be
Description directly responsible for all the following activities:
• (a) Placing and supervising children in out-of-home
care. Social service workers shall work directly with
the children, their families, and other relevant
individuals and be primarily responsible for the
development, implementation, and review of service
plans for the children and their families.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation There are concerns regarding the facility's placement decisions
with a youth given sexual abuse concerns.
Investigation Maternal Grandmother was interviewed via telephone on
June 5, 2025. She stated Youth A has been placed in her care for
several years. The case has been referred for adoption and there
is currently a competing party. Youth A has monthly visits with
Competing Party who resides in Ohio.
Maternal Grandmother stated the visits with Competing Party
started just prior to Christmas 2024. They are currently one time
per month and last 3-5 days. She reported there is usually a 6-
year-old cousin of Youth A that is also in the home during visits
with competing party. Youth A reported to her 6-year-old cousin
“pulled my pants down and kissed my butt and pee bug” during a
visit with competing party in March 2025. Maternal Grandmother
stated she asked Youth A if he told cousin to stop and he stated
6

yes, and cousin told him not to tell anyone. Maternal Grandmother
clarified Youth A refers to his penis as “pee bug”. Maternal
Grandmother stated she asked Youth A the next day if that has
happened before and he stated yes but couldn’t recall how many
times. She stated she emailed Youth A’s LGAL and Adoption
worker. She stated she reported the concerns to Ohio Child
Services and believes Vista Maria also reported it. Complainant
stated she never heard the outcome of the reports to Ohio Child
Services.
In April 2025 competing party picked up Youth A for a visit during
Easter break. Approximately 5 hours later Youth A was brought
back to Maternal Grandmother due to the overnight visit being
cancelled as a precaution due to concerns reported. Maternal
Grandmother stated no one from the agency informed her what
was going on. There was a court hearing on May 16, 2025, and
during the court hearing there was no discussion regarding the
concerns reported or any safety plan that was put in place. After
the hearing overnight visits with the competing party resumed and
Youth A had an overnight visit from May 23-26, 2025. She stated
the LGAL contacted her and informed her that a safety plan was
put in place but didn’t provide any details of the safety plan.
During a court hearing on May 16, 2025, Adoption worker was
asked by the court how visits with Competing Party have been
going. She reported to the court the visits were going to continue
in May 2025. Maternal Grandmother stated nothing was
mentioned regarding the overnight visit being cancelled in April
2025 or the reason why. Complainant stated there was no
indication during the hearing the judge was aware of the concerns
that had been reported.
Adoption worker was interviewed via telephone on June 10,
2025. She stated she has been assigned to the case since June
2024. She stated Youth A currently resides with Maternal
Grandmother. Youth A currently has court ordered visitation with
Competing Party. Competing Party resides in Ohio and visits
occur every month.
Adoption worker stated a cousin of Youth A is sometimes present
at the home of Competing Party during his monthly visitation. The
cousin is 4 months older than Youth A. After a visit with
Competing Party in March 2025, Adoption worker was notified of
concerns Youth A’s cousin may have touched him inappropriately.
After the incident Adoption worker contacted Children Services in
Ohio and reported the concerns but they wouldn’t assign a
7

complaint due to Youth A residing in Michigan. She contacted the
police department in Michigan and was told they were not
assigning the complaint to an officer. They were hoping if law
enforcement in Michigan became involved a CARE interview
could be completed with Youth A. She contacted Oakland County
Care House twice to inquire if they would complete an interview
with Youth A and never got a response. In May 2025 Adoption
worker stated she re-filed the complaint in Ohio and they did not
assign for investigation. There is a safety plan that Youth A and
the cousin are not to be left alone. If the cousin stays overnight,
they are not to be in the same room. She spoke with the cousin’s
parents, and they reported they spoke with both of their children,
and both report the incident did not occur. A complaint was also
filed in Michigan. Competing Party has agreed to follow any safety
plan the agency put in place. As a precaution, Youth A did not
have an overnight visit with competing party in April 2025.
Adoption worker stated before resuming overnight visits with
Competing Party the agency wanted to contact Michigan
Children’s Institute (MCI) and notify law enforcement. The agency
met with MCI on April 29, 2025, and they didn’t feel there was any
risk of harm and visits should resume. Adoption worker stated
during the most recent court hearing on May 16, 2025, the
incident was not brought up however she included a summary in
the court report submitted prior to the hearing. Adoption worker
stated she believes it was also mentioned in the LGAL’s report to
the court.
Adoption supervisor was interviewed via telephone on June
13, 2025. She stated upon receiving allegations of inappropriate
touching of Youth A by a cousin during a visit with Competing
Party the agency acted appropriately. They immediately made
Child Services complaints in Ohio, where Competing Party resides
and the location of the alleged incident, as well as Michigan. They
also contacted law enforcement in Michigan and none of the
agencies opened investigations. The agency implemented safety
plans that included no unsupervised contact between Youth A and
cousin and cousin is not to stay the night when Youth A is in the
home. In addition, the overnight visit in April 2025 was cancelled
and only resumed after conferring with LGAL and MCI. The
agency is trying to get a forensic interview scheduled with Kids
Talk. A facetime call occurred during Youth A’s visit with
Competing Party in May 2025 with Adoption worker and LGAL to
ensure the safety plan was being followed and Youth A felt safe.
Documents reviewed:
8

• Court orders from October 31, 2023-February 20, 2025,
that all state Youth A is to have visitation with competing
party. May 16, 2025, court order has not been
entered/uploaded.
• May 16, 2025, court report submitted by Adoption worker
notes Child Services complaint regarding visit with
Competing Party. Report states overnight visits were
cancelled until agency could meet with MCI. MCI and LGAL
supported overnight, unsupervised visitation resume.
• March 31, 2025, social work contact states Adoption worker
made referrals with Michigan and Ohio Centralized Intake
regarding allegations Youth A was inappropriately touched
during overnight visit with Competing Party.
• April 28, 2025, social work contact states agency met with
MCI to discuss allegations. MCI recommends overnight
visitation with competing party resume.
• March 31, 2025, safety plan signed by Competing Party.
Youth A and his cousin will not be alone together
unsupervised.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance. Based on completed
interviews and review of Youth A’s MISACWIS file the agency
responded appropriately to allegations Youth A was sexually
abused by a young cousin. Upon receiving the allegations,
Adoption worker made Child services complaints in Ohio and
Michigan. Law enforcement in Michigan was also contacted and
none of those agencies initiated an investigation. Overnight
visitation was suspended and only resumed after consulting with
MCI and LGAL. Safety plans were put in place to address the
concerns and there is no indication the safety plans are not being
followed.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
9

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
